block.p: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

New College Graduates Are Planning to Flee Iraq Iraq's college graduates are ending their studies shattered and eager to leave the country. In interviews with more than 30 students from seven universities, all but four said they hoped to flee immediately after receiving their degrees. A1

A Sunni insurgent group released a videotape that showed the military identification cards of two missing American soldiers who were captured last month south of Baghdad and said they had been killed. A14

Taylor Boycotts His Trial Charles Taylor, one of Africa's most tyrannical warlords and the former president of Liberia, refused to appear in court and sent word that he was firing his lawyer, apparently wanting to deflect attention from proceedings that aim to cover a decade of warfare and cruelty. A15

Putin and Bush to Meet on Iran As tensions rise between Washington and Moscow, President Bush and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia may use a summit meeting in Germany to focus on slowing Iran's ability to produce nuclear fuel. A6
Mr. Putin said Russia could benefit from longer presidential terms, though he again ruled out the possibility that he would remain in office after the expiration of his second term next year. A6

China Offers First Climate Plan With the world's industrial powers gathering in Germany, China released its first strategy on climate change, which promises to improve energy efficiency but rejects any caps on greenhouse gas. A12
NATIONAL A16-21

Judges Dismiss Charges Against Two Detainees The government's new system for trying Guantánamo detainees was thrown into turmoil when military judges in separate decisions dismissed war crimes charges against two detainees.
A1

Point System on Immigration As Congress returns from a recess and resumes work on the immigration bill, a point system will be at the heart of the debate because it would change the criteria for picking future immigrants.
A1
Congressman Is Indicted Representative William J. Jefferson, the Louisiana Democrat, was indicted by a federal grand jury in Virginia, which charged him with 16 corruption-related felony counts.
A1

AIDS Patients in Puerto Rico Hundreds of H.I.V. and AIDS patients in Puerto Rico are not receiving vital medical care. The problem reflects a persistently overstretched health care budget accentuated by destructive rivalries between the commonwealth and the San Juan city governments.
A1
Ruling Favors Prosecutors The Supreme Court strengthened the hand of prosecutors in death penalty cases by making it easier to remove potential jurors who express ambivalence about the death penalty.

Senator Craig Thomas Dies Senator Craig Thomas, a three-term Republican from Wyoming, died just hours after his staff reported that the treatment he was receiving for leukemia was no longer working. A17
NEW YORK/REGION B1-6

Local Guyanese Puzzled By Airport Terror Plot News that three Guyanese and one Trinidadian man have been accused of plotting to attack Kennedy International Airport has met with bafflement in New York's Caribbean immigrant communities. B1

Doubts on Immigration Bill A survey of lawmakers from the New York region shows that they are every bit as divided about the immigration bill under consideration in Washington as many of their colleagues around the country are. B1
SCIENCE TIMES F1-8

Recognizing a Disorder For the first time, therapists and researchers petitioned the American Psychiatric Association to include ''sensory processing disorder'' in its influential guidebook of disorders. F1
Health & Fitness F5
BUSINESS DAY C1-12

Indecency Ruling A federal appeals court struck down the government policy that allows stations and networks to be fined if they broadcast shows containing profanities. The decision was a sharp rebuke for the Federal Communications Commission.
A1
Business Digest C2
OBITUARIES B7
Bill France Jr. The chairman of Nascar who transformed it into a multi-billion-dollar enterprise, he was 74. B7
EDITORIAL A22-23
Editorials: An unacceptable nominee; safe harbor for exploited children; Dr. Kevorkian's wrong way; Verlyn Klinkenborg on planting trees.
Columns: David Brooks and Bob Herbert.
